00050 static const unsigned int num_syscalls = 23;
00051 
00052 static void* syscalls[23] = {
00053    &syscallPrint_t, //Syscall 0 - printf prints to active terminal
00054    &postboxReadTop, //Syscall 1 - Copys the top of the postbox to location given
00055    &postboxPopTop, //Syscall 2 -Pops the top of the postbox
00056    &postboxHasNext, //Syscall 3 - Does the postbox have anything for the process to read?
00057    &getKeyMapping, //Syscall 4 - Get the key mapping for a scancode
00058    &schedulerBlockMe, //Syscall 5 - Pause the current process forfitting any remaining processing time
00059    &postboxSetFlags, //Syscall 6 - Set the process message flags (What it wants to know about)
00060    &calculate_free_frames, //Syscall 7 - Return the number of free frames available
00061    &get_page_size, //Syscall 8 - Return the size in bytes of each page
00062    &syscallRequestReboot, //Syscall 9 - Ask the kernel to reboot
00063    &syscallClocksPerSecond, //Syscall 10 - Get the number of clock cycles that occur every second
00064    &syscallGetSystemUptime, //Syscall 11 - Get the systems uptime in clocks
00065    &syscallClearscreen, //Syscall 12 - Clear the current terminal
00066    &syscallSetFgc, //Syscall 13 - Set the current terminals FGC
00067    &syscallSetBgc, //Syscall 14 - Set the current terminals BGC
00068    &syscallKillCurrentProcess, //Syscall 15 - Flag the current process to be destroyed
00069    &syscallProcessValid, //Syscall 16 - Does the iter given link to a valid process?
00070    &syscallGetPid, //Syscall 17 - Get the PID of the process linked to the iterator
00071    &syscallGetProcessingTime, //Syscall 18 - Get the processing time of the process
00072    &syscallGetName, //Syscall 19 - Get the name of the process linked to the iterator
00073    &syscallRequestExit, //Syscall 20 - Request exit of the current process (Supplied argument is used as the return value)
00074    &syscallRequestRunNewProcess, //Syscall 21 - Requests the execution of a new application (char* filename supplied)
00075    &syscallSetDebugMode //Syscall 22 - Requests the kernel change the debug mode to on or off
00076 };
00077 
00078 //Function: syscallHandler
00079 //Arguments: idt_call_registers_t regs
00080 //Return: idt_call_registers_t with new values of the registers
00081 //Description: Handles a syscall (Via interrupt 127) and returns a new set of registers
00082 idt_call_registers_t syscallHandler(idt_call_registers_t regs)
00083 {
00084 
00085    // Firstly, check if the requested syscall number is valid.
00086    // The syscall number is found in EAX.
00087    if (regs.eax >= num_syscalls)
00088        return;
00089 
00090 
00091 
00092    // Get the required syscall location.
00093    void *location = syscalls[regs.eax];
00094 
00095    // Don't know how many parameters the function wants, so just
00096    // push them all onto the stack in the correct order. The function will
00097    // use all the parameters it wants, pop them all back off afterwards.
00098    MEM_LOC ret;
00099 
00100    //TODO: I'm not quite sure, the * might break it. testt
00101 
00102    asm volatile (" \
00103                    push %1; \
00104                    push %2; \
00105                    push %3; \
00106                    push %4; \
00107                    push %5; \
00108                    call *%6; \
00109                    pop %%ebx; \
00110                    pop %%ebx; \
00111                    pop %%ebx; \
00112                    pop %%ebx; \
00113                    pop %%ebx; \
00114                 " : "=a" (ret) : "r" (regs.edi), "r" (regs.esi), "r" (regs.edx), "r" (regs.ecx), "r" (regs.ebx), "r" (location));
00115 
00116    //Ret the return value of registers_t to ret. Its pushed to eax before the interrupt returns (iret instruction) allowing the process that was executing before the syscall to handle it
00117    regs.eax = ret;
00118 
00119    return regs;
00120 }
00121 
00122 void kernelInitializeSyscalls()
00123 {
00124         register_interrupt_handler (127, &syscallHandler); //Syscall = Interrupt 127
00125 
00126         return;
00127 }
